Actually, the problem with research into this and similar matters is that the research isn't capable of measuring the effect on the individual, only the average over populations.
It's entirely possible that only 50% of people experience such effects and biases and 50% not do so. All the research can claim is that on average, the effect is felt among humans, and since it obviously won't be negative, even if only 1% of humans feel the effect then that is enough to create an average positive effect.

4:40 "We know beyond a shadow of a doubt that homoeopathy does not have any effect beyond placebo".

There has been some support in the medical literature including mainstream journals (e.g., Lancet), using double blind placebo studies and meta-analysis of these, for the efficacy of some homoeopathic remedies. A hunt around Google Scholar turned a few in under 10 minutes of searching and browsing abstracts (below).

Your claim, quoted above, is therefore shown to be spurious.

Cucherat M, Haugh MC, Gooch M, Boissel JP. Evidence of clinical efficacy of homeopathy. A meta‐analysis of clinical trials. HMRAG. Homeopathic Medicines Research Advisory Group.
Eur J Clin Pharmacol 2000; 56: 27–33.
Conclusions: There is some evidence that homeopathic treatments are more effective than placebo; however, the strength of this evidence is low because of the low methodological quality of the trials. Studies of high methodological quality were more likely to be negative than the lower quality studies. Further high quality studies are needed to confirm these results.


Gibson RG, Gibson SLM, Macneill AD, Buchanan WW. The place for non-pharmaceutical therapy in chronic rheumatoid arthritis: A critical study of homœopathy.
Br Homeopath J 1980; 69: 121-133.
A two-part trial is reported in which patients with rheumatoid arthritis were treated with homœopathy. In the first part of the trial, 54 patients on homœopathy were compared with 41 patients on salicylate over the course of a year. 66 per cent of the patients on homœopathy improved, as compared with 14.6 per cent of the patients on salicylate.
In the second part of the trial, 46 patients took part in a double-blind study in which homœopathy was compared with placebo for a period of three months. The patients on homœopathy improved significantly while those on placebo did not.
It was also shown that it may well be possible to predict which patients are most likely to respond to homœopathic treatment.
No toxic effects were observed in any patient on homœopathy whereas 39 per cent of the patients on salicylate experienced toxic effects.



Linde K, Clausius N, Ramirez G et al. Are the clinical effects of homeopathy placebo effects? A meta‐analysis of placebo‐controlled trials.
Lancet 1997; 350: 834–43.
Findings
The combined odds ratio for the 89 studies entered into the main meta-analysis was 2·45 (95% CI 2·05, 2·93) in favour of homoeopathy. The odds ratio for the 26 good-quality studies was 1·66 (1·33, 2·08), and that corrected for publication bias was 1·78 (1·03, 3·10). Four studies on the effects of a single remedy on seasonal allergies had a pooled odds ratio for ocular symptoms at 4 weeks of 2·03 (1·51, 2·74). Five studies on postoperative ileus had a pooled mean effect-size-difference of −0·22 standard deviations (95% Cl −0·36, −0·09) for flatus, and −0·18 SDs (−0·33, −0·03) for stool (both p<0·05).
Interpretation
The results of our meta-analysis are not compatible with the hypothesis that the clinical effects of homoeopathy are completely due to placebo. However, we found insufficient evidence from these studies that homoeopathy is clearly efficacious for any single clinical condition. Further research on homoeopathy is warranted provided it is rigorous and systematic.

Usually your videos are amazing and I recommend them to everyone but this time you're off. As a student of Medicine, who has studied Organic Chemistry, while also actively being in Corporate World and having ties in the medical industry, I just wanted to mention a couple of things:

1. Water does remember what you put in it, as long as certain conditions are met. You made 'water remembering what you put in it' sound like magic yet talked about horses having placebo effects as if its science, there is bias in that. Hydrogen bonding is very much real. Homeopaths dont just 'shake' water rigorously like you made it out to be. You're amazing when you do your research so I urge you to look up concepts of enantionmers and diasteriomers. Orientation is huge when it comes to organic compounds.

2. "We have proven with 100% certainty that homeopathic medicine has 0 effect" is same as saying "We have proven with 100% certainty that day by day each modern medicine's treatment is becoming more harmful and less successful." You look at treatment for even the simplest of issues and you'll see that modern medicine has 40-60 (and sometimes 49-51) ratio of help v. harm. I'm not even talking big diseases like cancer but take even small tooth pain for example: who is to say that the remedy isn't more painful than the problem itself? Not to mention recurring. A patient cured is a customer lost.

3. Placebo Effect. You talked about placebo effect as science lol where it is all psychology with no equation to prove its validity. You're saying the human brain is so powerful that it can heal itself - this is science. But homeopathy, which has active ingredients, is not science. I mean I completely agree that human brain is so powerful that it can heal itself (I do meditate and know powers of meditation) but how does our confidence in a medicine translate to our dogs/horses getting better? Purely from our body language? That is 3rd party transfer of emotions and sure, if that works - I fail to see how 1:10 or 1:100 potency doesn't work. Have there been studies to show 100% effect of placebo in 3rd party individuals?

4. You showed MRIs/biotech side of medicine but failed to grasp how modern medicine also has horrible chemicals where the side-effects are never ending. Its not a competition of homeopathic's fake cure v. medicine's perfect cure; the competition is between minor cure + no harm v. better cure + more harm.

OK, so, if homeopathy is the thing with the idea of super diluted medicine, then things like essential oils and herbs aren't technically homeopathic remedies? A lot of medicine was synthesized from herbs, so it's not like herbs and essential oils (concentrated herbs) have imaginary benefits.
As far as actual homeopathic things, I have experience with just one, which is a mineral substance, so I'm not really doubting its effects, as I started taking it at a point not, really expecting or knowing to expect any effects, and actually saw an improvement in my health in spheres covered by the mineral. I've personally had both good and bad encounters with homeopathy. I think the point to remember is that you can't lump all of the products together. I've had a great experience using products like Calms Forte and to a greater extent Nerve Tonic to calm my nerves with the latter product even calming me down from full-blown panic attacks. I've then had poor experiences with other products, most notably any homeopathic pain reliever and any kind of mouth spray. The pain reliever is too weak and the mouth spray is almost certainly a gimmick. Just because something is homeopathic doesn't mean it's automatically a gimmick nor does it automatically mean that it works. Also, keep in mind that many people are affected in different ways by different medications, so what works for one person might not work for another and vice versa.

I am a fan of the placebo effect, and agree that it can be a factor, as can giving attention in the form of a long interview. Studies show thst prayer and touch also help peoples health. However, homeopathy works in India where interviews are very quick. As well, I've seen dramatic effects in accidental dosing. Since no one knew of the dosing, placebo effect is moot. If placebo effect is the only factor, any remedy would work, but this isn't the case. However, practitioners sometimes use a placebo (a sugar pill without any homeopathic medicine applied). This can be with or without the patient's knowledge (forbidden in some places). This is because sometimes folks have a desire to take more medicine when it isn't indicated. They just need to wait for the medicine to finish acting. One commenter thought that accidental overdosing by taking an entire tube of remedy should cause death if the medicine were real. This is not the case. It would be interesting to take note of any changes in that person that they did not realize were due to the remedy.

Honestly, homeopathy and other alternative medicines seems to have only one thing that goes for it: personalization, and individualization. The thing that made me recognize alternative medicine’s true strengths (it shouldn’t replace conventional medicine, obviously) was one article: why black women were more likely to opt for midwives. They didn’t feel seen, they didn’t feel safe, and a lot of times black women’s medical concerns about their pregnancies were dismissed, or even made into points of ridicule (yes, even to that point. For one example, a woman had a stillbirth, and was told that if she screamed from pain, she would not receive any painkillers. That’s like, a whole other level of fucked up). And if you wanna get into stats, not just anecdotes, black women are twice as likely to die in childbirth compared to white women, even if they’re the same economic class. Black babies were three times as likely to die, even when taking into account things like genetics or other things that are out of the infant’s or their mothers’ control. So yeah, black women were, and still are, more likely to go to licensed midwives (especially trained ones, a lot of midwives need licenses in nursing), because of those fears and risks of race based mistreatment. It made sense to me; that’s where I feel alternative medicine has some positives. It’s the psychology.

I worked for a company that sold tea for the most common issues. Hypertension, diabetes etc. I resigned 3 days ago from there after 1.5 years.

Some of my experiences:

After drinking the tea for 3-6 months, some people have stopped taking their medicine for high blood pressure after years of regular consumption of their pills.

I sold a 3 month therapy to one woman who was a diabetic (on pills) for 20 years. By chance, the system gave me the same customer to follow up in her experiences (and to see if she wants/needs more). She told me herself she is not using her pills anymore at all, and the tea was holding her sugar levels at normal.

I had a guy who had prostate issues for a decade and took pills. He had to go pee every 1 hour the whole night. On the 4th day of drinking the tea, he called me to give his sincere thanks, and to say that just after 4 days, he managed to sleep for 3 hours without interruption, which was a huge early success for him.

We have had parents who have tried everything for their children who have been put on insulin, call us and thank us because finally they found something that worked in reducing the sugar levels.

This is unrelated to our products, but one woman told me a doctor told her that her thyroid issues would last for the rest of her life, and she would have to take medication for it. She was in her forties back then. She found a certain type of fish, that she ate 3 times per week for 6 months. When she went back for a checkup, she told me her doctor was baffled and told her that her thyroid had no issues at all. The doc asked her what she did, and she angrily told her "Well I didn't take you pills!"

People tell me that modern medicine is working and efficient. I disagree to some extent. How is it efficient to have to take pills for decades? Hypertension, diabetes, blood thinners, prostate issues etc. Those can be regulated with lifestyle choices for many people, yet doctors (at least in my region), jump at the chance to put people on lifetime medication use.

A positive attitude definitely makes a difference in results, but it's not just positive attitude, because more often than not, the people who came to us tried many different things before with no results, so most of the time, they are skeptical when they start.

Of course, like any medication, not everyone had amazing results. The main issue was that many people expect overnight cures for things that they have allowed to go on for years, but natural products work a lot slower than pills, and many people don't have the patience or discipline.

I have a different opinion on this, but first let me say what I agree with and give some background. I have been using Homeopathic remedies for over 50 years. (I also do believe that vaccines are effective and am fully vaccinated + booster). I agree that Homeopathy has become big business. This has not always been the case. I watched the transition take place as Boiron became a "market player." In fact, there was no "market" before Boiron began packing the Homeopathy advisory panels with their members and strongly advocating for practices that benefited their brand. They also pushed the use of C potencies, which were not widely available to the general public before Boiron made them available. Boiron's aggressive tactics have influenced the demise of at least one very old and established company, and seem to have caused others to change their policies. So, I agree that Homeopathy has become big business and that the profits have driven many decision about the remedies. Second, I agree that using 30C+ remedies does not make sense. Until Bioron's marketing made it difficult to easily get lower potencies I never used a C dilution. I do not know how they work, and I cannot say I have ever seen definite results by taking one. I have many years experience using 6X dilutions and have seen their effectiveness in a number of instances. The most notable is the use of Arnica 6X for pre and post- surgery, and for burses. I believe that there are double blind clinical studies that support this use. If you mix these studies in with others you get an "average no effect," which as Kurzgesagt knows well has no meaning. The question is not "do all Homeopathic remedies work" but "do some homeopathic remedies work for specific conditions." The answer to the first question is almost certainly no. The answer to the second is, in my experience, yes.

I really had a split opinion about homeopathy for most of my life. When I was younger, I had a benign tumor in my left nasal cavity and jaw and had to have several surgeries. But it grew back after about 3 months to its original size three times. So when cancer treatment was deemed too high of a risk for me to develop actual cancer, my mom and I just made the decision to try homeopathy while doing surgical removal. A friend of hers had recommended it since he himself got alternative treatment for his cancer and swears on it ever since.
Basically, I took a few doses and had some face to face sessions with the homeopath... After that, I had to do several MRI scans in the span of a year, to see if the tumor began to grow anew. Surprisingly though, it never returned, and I'm still wondering- 8 years later- if the doctors did just finally get all of the diseased tissue so the cells couldn't multiply anymore, or if the homeopathy actually did something.

Like I said, I'm still pretty divided because I know that the concept shouldn't work... Kinda weird to think about :'D

I’m going to get fried alive by this, but here it goes:
a “homeopathy vs scientific method” comparison would be overly simplistic. The subject can and should be broken down through a different lense: the aggregation of knowledge comes through trial and error from different sources and a myriad of variables come into play.

Homeopathy has given good results in many ailments past the placebo effect and the divergence from more invasive treatments. But it’s probably not at all correlated with some of its weirdest principles.
It would be arrogance and not scientific method that would dismiss an entire system of diagnosis and treatment because some of its foundational bases are dissonant with what we agreed we know for sure.

The “like cure like” principle, for instance, has been used in other classic medicine approaches and dilution does play an important role (however not to the “memory of water” point).
If used to trigger a immunitary response, both principles are actively used in classic medicine.
The principles at play aren’t crazy at all. The crazy bit would be to dismiss the entire pool of potentially relevant medical data from homeopathic treatments because they might distort or contradict the current structure or knowledge.

Just to be clear, I am NOT saying homeopathy is the way to go, I’m saying centuries of usage deserve a longer more varied study before deciding it is entirely worthless from a scientific perspective. We might very well be missing some details.

Homeopathy works for certain things. It's disappointing to see this channel repeat the same old tropes against homeopathy. Yes, the theory doesn't make sense, but that could simply mean that our theory is not to an appropriate level as yet.

Argument against water having memory: the video explains that if water has memory, then it should have memory of everything and there should be an essence of everything in it from poop to salt and toxins etc. But the water we drink is not simply filtered and diluted. It's treated by quite a number of methods before pumped into our pipes.

Placebo: so many people have been suffering from all kinds of chronic ailments, going to all kinds of doctors. Yet placebo never helped them then. Yet when they go to a homeopath and their ailment happens to get cured, then suddenly placebo kicked in only then?

Nice homeopathic doctors: There's plenty of really good doctors even of conventional medicine throughout the world especially in private practice. Yet these good feelings didn't cure certain ailments. What is so great about a homeopathic doctor that the placebo he imparts is practically miraculous healing?

It doesn't cure cancer: That's an unfair comparison. Homeopathy does not claim to cure cancer. Paracetamol doesn't cure cancer either, yet it's not invalidated based on that. Most conventional medicine doesn't cure cancer. A medication must be judged against what it is claimed to cure, nothing more.

Anti vaxxers and anti conventional medicine: False equivalency. I've never met a homeopath who discourages vaccination or any conventional medicine for that matter. At most, I've met homeopaths who discourage use of anti-biotics for silly things like influenza, which is what most modern doctors discourage as well.

Big pharma: That's blown way out of proportion, and encouraging selective skepticism. Every industry has lobby groups.

Homeopathy persists because it works for certain ailments. There's no way it would persist for so long and at such a large presence if there was no bottom line of it working for many patients. There's numerous other alternative medicines that really are on the fringes, but homeopathy still persists in large presence. There's even lots of GP's who recommend it for certain things. There's simply just many who have a medical machismo over conventional medicine.

One of the best examples of the transferable placebo effect I observed in my psychology class was the case of a horse that could supposedly do math. Of course there is a double edged sword with more personal medicine. Sure, the people who do get treated get a much better experience, but that comes at a steep price. It means far, far fewer people get any sort of treatment whatsoever. Doctors can't treat as many people, and by the law of supply and demand, prices soar. As with most things, a balance of efficiency and personalization is probably the best outcome. Personalization is also much more important for long term chronic conditions. You don't need a multi-hour consultation for a broken bone or the flu, but if that broken bone leaves you needing therapy for months after it is stabilized then a consultation becomes very important.

Why is no one talking about the fact that the part of the reason that medical school is so selective is so that doctors become scarcer and have higher wages? Studying medicine is quite challenging no doubt but similar to other hyper competitive fields like Law, they artificially lower the number of people graduating as a doctor or a lawyer by putting certain barriers. Making the educational environment hyper competitive and stressful is one way to weed out people at the college level. Increasingly difficult/competitive entrance exams are another way of selecting people out of the system. A friend of mine recently passed the bar and it was one of the worst and most traumatic experiences ever even though he passed. The system is literally designed to pummel you and beat you senseless until you don't know which way is up. The end result? Those who made it through have higher wages and more job security. However, no one talks about the fact that to make these environments so selective and hyper competitive requires money which makes training a neurosurgeon, for example. extremely expensive. This, in turn, increases medical costs (or legal costs) not to mention the fact that you end up with fewer doctors in the workforce. When the pandemic hit, these shortages were felt (especially by the doctors). In conclusion, spending more time on patients isn't possible. It would be against the American Medical Association or the American Bar Association's interest to admit more people into the profession.

The next time I had a laryngitis I did the same and it went away pretty quickly. The third time I had one I didn't buy those pills because they're pretty pricy. I saw my doctor again to tell him that since I get a laryingitis pretty often if I should be worried. About Homeopathy

In all the serious research that has been carried out on homeopathy, no efficacy has been demonstrated. Do you know what homeopathy is? Homeopathy claims to cure by diluting certain substances so much that the active substance is no longer present at all.
The most common dilution they use is D60, that is, such a dilution is as great as one molecule of active substance in 20 trillion times the contents of all the oceans.
This is dilution 10^-60
At dilution 10^-80 there is 1 molecule of the active ingredient to all matter in the universe,
And to take the antifreeze drug Oscillococcinum, this is a dilution of 10-400 of duck liver and duck heart.
So a dilution of one molecule in 10 ^320 universes, a 10 with 320 zeros times the universe. Do you really think this is effective?

Let's do a thought experiment,
We're gonna make the assumption that water actually has the magical memory property. And we're going to make Oscillococcinum.
We slaughter a duck and take some of its heart and liver and leave it for 40 days. We filter and freeze-dry that, and we're going to dilute it. We take some water, add it to it, shake, take a little of the solution and dilute it further with water. This we repeat until we have the unimaginable dilution of 10^-400
Now I wonder, how do you know what you have diluted? The duck's liver? Yes, but what about the contaminants in the water? You have a place where you are pouring and diluting, the air is full of dust, bacteria, viruses, fungi and even algae spores.
Even in the most modern chip factories, they are only able to remove everything from the air to a certain degree. What about water? How do you know that your water does not contain other trace elements? Or has it? Water is almost as old as the universe, so it has had quite a few bedfellows in its existence.
And the bottles you are diluting it in?
They all bring traces, albeit small ones.
That the duck's liver is an active element in flu medication is therefore unlikely, not only because of the dilution, but also because it is virtually impossible to know what else has been infinitely diluted.
And then you've done your best to keep your preparation pure within certain limits and then you put the solution on sugar, sugar is hygroscopic and draws moisture from the air. Does that moisture also have a memory and what does it contain? Your Oscillococcinum goes into plastic tubes.

While the video was great, I find the last part of how modern medicine should learn from homeopathy to be a bit naive. How exactly do you propose we change the modern medical system that we can accommodate spending hours on a single patient visit? The entire incentive system makes it so that doctors get paid less and are seen as less valuable if they see fewer patients. Hospitals want to hire as few people as possible and have them be as efficient as possible to make as much money as possible. Consults and visits do not generate nearly as much revenue as procedures, treatments and tests. And talking with patients for a long time and making them feel happy often does little in terms of actually curing diseases. And all that time spent making everyone feel heard is time that medical professionals could be spending helping other people.

So while it's a nice notion to say that modern medicine should pay attention to the human need of patients, doing so is a ridiculously hard task. Homeopathy only gets away with doing this because they're con artists. Of course they spend more time and make people like them better when their goal is to scam people out of their money.

I would love to see a video in which how we could change the medical system to both be efficient and take care of the human need could be done.

This documentary is very funny, not because it is accurate, but because it tries to falsely present itself as a "neutral" documentary. The sources of the documentary say it all: they only quote Internet pages of a German lobby called "Gesellschaft zur wissenschaftlichen Untersuchung von Parawissenschaften" or "Information Network Homeopath". Here in this commentary I will only stop at the few documents from reputable sites and skip the blog pamphlets.

1. In the video, classical homeopathy is mentioned, however in the desription cheatingly puts a meta-analysis published in 2017 by Mathie et al that does not evaluate classical homeopathy, but non-individualized homeopathy. The meta-analysis published in 2014 by the same author on individualized homeopathy is ignored:

"Medicines prescribed in individualised homeopathy may have small, specific treatment effects. Findings are consistent with sub-group data available in a previous ‘global’ systematic review. The low or unclear overall quality of the evidence prompts caution in interpreting the findings. New high-quality RCT research is necessary to enable more decisive interpretation" (2014).

Someone might criticize the conclusion on the grounds that it mentions that the trials were of low quality, but this refers to the evidence in general (both positive and negative). Even with this limitation, the meta-analysis was able to show that the set of higher quality trials with lower risk of bias demonstrated a robust and consistent effect greater than the placebo.

2. Kurzgesagt team cite as support the review published in 2015 by the Australian government, but ignore that in 2019 the director of the NHRMC was forced to acknowledge that: "Contrary to some claims, the review did not conclude that homeopathy was ineffective" (Source: Second Report released). The correct interpretation of the second report that the evidence was not "sufficient", this statement is very different from the one spread by the media saying that the report "had shown that homeopathy is placebo". This report was included in a systematic megareview, along with all global meta-analyses, and did not affect the outcome. The authors concluded:

"In conclusion, evidence for the effectiveness of human and veterinary homeopathy in general, and in particular, of homeopathic treatment for infections, is available. Especially, individualized homeopathy demonstrates effects at all quality levels according to Cochrane criteria, even in the methodologically high-quality studies. As in most areas of veterinary medicine and medicine, further good/excellent studies are necessary" (2020).

3. The EASAC report is cited as support. It should be recalled that this report was not peer-reviewed and, suspiciously obviously cites the Mathie (2014) meta-analysis. At the time, Peter Fisher showed that the report had no scientific basis, but mere cherry picking:

"The EASAC statement ‘cherry picks’ the evidence, systematically selecting negative publications and citing almost exclusively hostile commentary and opinion pieces. To take a few examples: in 2007 Homeopathy published a special issue on ‘Memory of Water’: this included 13 scientific papers.2 Of these, the EASAC statement references the only one which took a sceptical view. In claiming that there is no evidence beyond placebo the statement ignores the 43 published systematic reviews of homeopathy as a whole, individualized, or for specific conditions or groups of conditions. Of these 21 were clearly or tentatively positive and 9 inconclusive.3 It discusses only the Shang meta-analysis, ignoring the fact that it failed to meet elementary standards of quality and transparency.4 It did not reference the publications on which it was based; on the contrary all clues to their identity were removed. In another fundamental flaw the data were ‘dredged’: during the review process the inclusion criteria for study inclusion were changed from ‘high quality’ to ‘larger high quality’. It has since been shown that, had the goalposts not been moved and the meta-analysis conducted as originally intended, the result would have been positive.5 Its negative result was almost entirely due to a single large trial on prevention of muscle soreness in long-distance runners." (2017).

4. Finally, an article written by David Robert Grimmes and published in the Focus on Alternative and Complementary Therapies is cited. This article is not an experiment, but merely an essay attempting to demonstrate that it is "physically impossible" for homeopathy to work. The author starts from a faulty premise and selectively cites evidence that suits him. The article was published in 2012, it is quite widely outdated. The latest systematic review of the evidence to debunk the David Grimmes' nonsense was recently published. The review showed that there is evidence of high methodological quality that has been reproduced:

"To conclude, the most promising techniques used so far are NMR relaxation, optical spectroscopy, and electrical impedance measurements. In these three areas, several sets of replicated high-quality experiments provide evidence for specific physicochemical properties of homeopathic preparations (2019)."

the head of the UK National Health Service (NHS), Simon Stevens, publicly expressing his “serious concerns” about the “fundamentally flawed” practice of homeopathy. The two public health experts were of the opinion that official accreditation of this system of medicine was responsible for giving the public a false impression that homeopathy was a form of treatment with scientific and clinical backing. The thing about homeopathy is that it isn't, indeed, something you should take as your main treatment, since it has mainly an effect on your emotional side (which is, by no means, easily measured since it isn't a physical and logical pattern of the body). I agree you have to take meds to solve your cold, but you have to remember that our bodies aren't things like machines which you can just input some pills and say "yay, it's cured". And I'm saying it because I don't want people to go to extremes and think you should banish alternative therapies that have some prospects on helping or relieving people's daily suffering- I repeat, it DOES NOT CURE YOU, but it at least helps you to get by in life, and, sometimes, that's all you need to definitely recover from it, rather than solve it one time and have to repeatedly return to the hospital, cause you're too stressed.

In cases like autoimmune diseases, managing your emotional side is the best you can do to cope with the flares AND the amazing side effects of the meds you take. It's a personal experience, and really, I almost fell into depression if it wasn't by homeopathy. Placebo effect is all about faith. And it's not religious faith, it's faith in a sense of getting yourself straight and believing in your own recovery.

So, my message here is: please, do not admonish it too much. Our so godly adored science isn't omnipotent, and although I love it (to the point I got into college to major in Biology) I won't stop someone to do whatever they need to obtain a healthy life. Though, I will scold someone if they are being too impetuous about something (like, consuming miraculous recipes instead of going to the doctor? That's a big no). My policy is, do something safe first. Go to the hospital. If it isn't solving, if you are in your dead end, if there are no more alternatives, if you're suffering from it, then you should go look for alternative therapies, complementary or not.

The world isn't all about scientific proved facts, as much as it isn't all about secret magical energy vibes. Be careful to not act smug like those "crazy guys addicted to crazy holy powder with no scientific basis". I mean, it's that kind of thinking- "those guys are idiots, why they don't do as we say" that is keeping people away from believing in science.

Alright, a few things should be mentioned additionally:
Modern medicine DID learn a few things from homeopathy. Back then, before it becam utter nonsense. And that's the usage of plants and herbs and even poisons and mold for treatment. From there it developed into what we know today, where it's partly replaced by synthetic or synthetizised ingredients, or only very specific ingredients of the plants are extracted and made into medicine in concentrated form.
Since then, homeopathy has kinda split: The globuli fraction (and some other sub groups, that think drinking bleach is a natural healing thing) and herbal medicine. Herbal medicine is far closer to modern medicine than sugar-water-sharlatans, just that it's more in a natural (less concentrated) state. While there are still homeopathists that prescribe herbal based stuff, it's often nonsense like back flowers essence (again no harm, but also no use).
And then there are normal doctors, who also prescribe herbal medicine, like for example pills that are made of 12 different plants and herbs that are known to have a slight effect against bacteria, pressed into a pill. Unfortunately though, while 'Homeopathist' is a more or less recognized medical job (without any studying of medicine involved whatsoever), 'herbalist' is not. That's why you will find many family doctors in my country, who are also official 'homeopathists' but in actuality, they are herbalists. And they only prescribe herb medicine, if they can be sure that the pacient will recover without hardcore antibiotics etc.

relevant scientific knowledge about physics, chemistry, biochemistry and biology[8][9][10][11][12][13] gained since at least the mid-19th century[14] confirms that homeopathic remedies have no active content. They are biochemically inert, and have no effect on any known disease.[8][15][16] Hahnemann's theory of disease, centered around principles he termed miasms, is inconsistent with subsequent identification of viruses and bacteria as causes of disease. Clinical trials have been conducted, and generally demonstrated no objective effect from homeopathic preparations.[17][18][19]:206[20] The fundamental implausibility of homeopathy as well as a lack of demonstrable effectiveness has led to it being characterized within the scientific and medical communities as quackery and nonsense.[3][21][22]

After assessments of homeopathy, national and international bodies have recommended the withdrawal of government funding. Australia, the United Kingdom, Switzerland and France,[23] as well as the European Academies' Science Advisory Council, and the Commission on Pseudoscience and Research Fraud of Russian Academy of Sciences each concluded that homeopathy is ineffective, and recommended against the practice receiving any further funding.[24][25][26][27] Notably, France and England, where homeopathy was formerly prevalent, are in the process of removing all public funding. The National Health Service in England ceased funding homeopathic remedies in November 2017[28][29] and asked the Department of Health in the UK to add homeopathic remedies to the blacklist of forbidden prescription items,[30] and France will remove funding by 2021.[31] In November 2018, Spain also announced moves to ban homeopathy and other pseudotherapies.[32]

This Kurzgesagt Video (KV) is an extremely simplistic misrepresentation of the evidence for homeopathy. As always, critics boil it down to: Its too diluted therefore it cant work. I urge anyone who wants to escape chemical medicine, to trust their own experience, not what some ill-informed talking head says. But I will address the points.

KV's first simplistic point is that a substance like Belladonna which causes fever will cure a fever. That is allopathic (conventional) medical thinking; match the drug to a few symptoms. Homeopathy is matching on the unique constellation of symptoms - mental, emotional and physical - that an individual is experiencing. Only if a remedy's symptoms match the individual's symptoms well, on all levels will it be effective.

Immediately KV jumps to Potentization, the process of dilution that is used to create remedies. Dr Hahnemann practiced long before he started diluting the remedies and he had cures with homeopathic (similar) medicines. Dilution is not necessary but makes the remedies more effective without the toxicity that accompanies all medicines. The dilution process is performed with distilled water and purified alcohol, not toilet water and ocean water!

Anyone skeptical of the effectiveness of extremely dilute remedies can perform a homeopathic proving which is the scientific foundation of homeopathy. Volunteers take an unknown remedy repeatedly over several days and the new never-before experienced symptoms - mental, emotional and physical - are carefully recorded. These are the constellation of symptoms that this remedy will cure in a sick person. After the volunteers stop taking the remedy the new symptoms eventually wear off, leaving them as before. This is a repeatable experiment that anyone can try to experience remedies' power for themselves.

Homeopathy has been successful not just in comparison to the lethality of 1800's medicine but also compared to modern conventional medicine. Homeopathy has 220+ years of well documented cures around the world with millions of doctors and patients, of even chronic diseases considered incurable by conventional medicine. Anyone doubtful can sit in on the clinics held by doctors and homeopathic medical schools and see the wide range of humanity cured of everything from hangnail to, yes, even cancer.

Hahnemann did impose very strict limitations on what his patients consumed and did, under his treatment. And present day homeopaths do discuss the same issues with their patients. But they have found that it is not necessary to be so strict. We can even work with patients who are taking allopathic drugs, and see results that the drugs cant account for.

Our modern healthier lives are Not primarily due to modern medicine's diagnostics, double blind studies and scientific evaluations. Read what Dr Ioannidis, Dr Horton (Lancet) and Dr Angell (New Eng Journ of Med) have written about the abysmal current state of medical science research, perhaps 50% of which is untrue! We live healthier because of cleaner air, water and better food - better lifestyles. And those gains are now being reversed by chemical ag and junk food.

There are lots of studies that show that homeopathy works better than Placebo. Conventional "Scientists" look at all those studies and say "that’s bad science" and ignore them. Homeopaths look at the studies that supposedly show it doesn’t work and say "that’s bad homeopathy". The two sides are never going to agree in this arena. That is why I urge the readers to experience it for themselves.

Organic farmers and ranchers use homeopathy on their plants and herd animals. I don’t think you can seriously make the case that this is transferred placebo effect. Farmers have to make a living and don’t risk it on something sketchy. Ranchers don’t have time to tuck their herd in bed at night.

The argument that it is only time that is working to the advantage of homeopathy is specious. The definition of a chronic illness is an illness that doesn’t spontaneously recover - its chronic! Yet homeopathy has a long well-documented history of cures of serious and incurable chronic illness, and rapid cures of serious acute illnesses. For example during the Spanish Flu 1918-20, homeopaths documented a 1.05% mortality rate out of 26,000+ cases while conventional docs had a 10-30% mortality rate.

As for homeopathy being "Big Pharma"! It’s the size of a pimple on the ugly monster of truly "Big Pharma".

Homeopathy is bad for public health!? The USA has the most expensive medicine with the worst outcomes in the industrialized world largely because there is no serious competition for allopathic medicine. A robust competition from other forms of medicine such as homeopathy, herbalogy and naturopathy would be nothing but good for the public's health.

Empathy is a much underestimated part of medicine and in fact needs to be recognized as such. A very good example of this is wound healing after a procedure: if the patient is happier, wounds tend to heal faster, if the patient is more stressed, they heal slower. This is most likely due to the fact that stress and it's hormones, e.g. cortisol, hinder wound healing in favor of other systems. So to put it bluntly: if the surgeon isn't nice to their patient, they shouldn't wonder why the wounds aren't healing.

Well I came across an oddity of logic, nothing to do with homeopathy but genetic ancestry :- we each have twenty thousand genes, but let's say thirty two thousand for mathematical simplicity. Each of us only passes on half our genes to any one child and they in turn only pass on half their genes to their children. Now, without any intermarriages, after sixteen generations ones fourteen greats grandchildren will only have inherited one gene from their fourteen greats grand parent. ie) each of us likewise have inherited potentially only one gene from a fourteen greats grand parent.
If ones goes further back we have a good chance of having an ancestor in which we have inherited zero genes and yet we would not have been born if they were not logically an ancestor. eg) If my great great.....great grand parents hadn't met, their son/ daughter my next most near ancestor could not have been born for them to marry and pass on genes to yet my next most near ancestor and so on to me, the actual pathway the gene dilution path takes for me to be born includes ancestors of whom I have inherited no genes due to dilution. Tbh, this is wholely a perspective on the institution of ameri/eurocentric homeopathy, and doesn't address or represent aspects of natural medicine which have come before or from other cultures - some which have even been adopted into modern clinical medicine. Two quick examples of these are the Egyptian usage of willow tree bark to remedy pain, which was adapted into aspirin, and the Sumerian/Ancient Greek use of poppies was eventually adapted to produce morphine and codeine (not to mention all the Asian and African herbs which also have been explored). I believe it's important to recognize the differences between what is covered in this video and actual natural medicines and their practices, as it is not always apparent the difference between the two.

Kurzgesagt, there are multiple ways doctors practice homeopathy. You don't have to use an ingredient that causes your symptoms. Instead, you first pinpoint the toxin or disease damaging your body, then you dilute that substance instead, with sucussions beyond the Avogadro number. Now there is a small amount of residual energy that the water retained even from the extreme dilutions, but that alone is barely going to do anything to you. You use a certain machine (often called a potentizer) to transfer your diluted toxin's energy field to a pure bottle of water, and use the machine to increase the energetic field in the pure bottle of water's newly gained toxin energy, and that's your homeopathic remedy that actual works.

After reading comments here, I'd love to share my experience of Homeopathy treatment.

I had dry eyes for 6 months, visited many opthalmologist, they had only one cure: Eye drops. Tried EVERY eye drop suggested by the Doctors, but all in vain.
Left with no options, I switched to Homeopathy and in 1 month, there's 99% relief. Now I just feel a bit uneasiness in eyes when I wake up in the morning, but it stays for only a minute or so.
Many of my family members are doctors in various specialities, and a close friend is also an assistant to a renowned Eye Specialist of the country, but everyone had only one solution of my problem: Eye drops. From 2 drops twice a day, it went to 2 drops in every 1 hour, and being a student it had started to affect my studies too.

What I've realised is Homeopathy is all about the experience of the practitioner. I'm an Indian and here in my city, there are many Homeopathy doctors who, in the name of social service, provide homeopathic treatment at less than $1 price. At the same time, there are many who don't leave a single chance to suck every penny you have. And I feel, Western world is full of such scammers, there's dearth of real homeopathic doctors. Even if they are genuine, they would be heck expensive.
For me, luckily I got a genuine doctor, who had recently graduated but had a lot of knowledge. After 2 trials of different medicines, he managed to get the perfect match as per my body composition. My treatment costs me less than $3 a month, which is even lesser than the cost of most of eye drops out there. I couldn't ask for more! Really grateful to the doctor. 🙏

In case of serious illness, it might take several rounds of trial and error to reach the single most suitable medicine. It's during this process, people start feeling that homeopathy is a waste, and only during this time you'll feel like doctors are just looting you (which they might). I've been to homeopathy doctors with over 20 years experience and their fees were really high, they mainly charged for their experience and goodwill. Otherwise, even a recent graduate doctor can suggest you the same medicine, which doesn't cost much, at least here in India these homeopathic medicines are cheaper than allopathic medicines.
There are many medicines in homeopathy that work instantly. Recently my doc suggested me a medicine for my severe cold, and in just 1 day, I felt relief in the symptoms. I could have a sound sleep after 2 days.

If science has not been able comprehend the working of Homeopathic medicines yet, that doesn't mean the medicines are ineffective, or Homeopathy is a placebo.
It's not only with Homeopathy, science is yet to fathom Ayurveda, Acupressure, Reiki. I've first hand positive experience with all these alternative medical approaches. These treatments mainly depend on the practitioner, and it's a really tough task to find a genuine one, even tougher if you're from Western Side of the globe.

Thanks for your time.

My mom died from cancer recently- she smoked for close to 20 years, but quit for over 10. She never went to a doctor, unless it was a serious injury, She never had a mammogram once in her life and she had never looked into the early warning signs of lung cancer, which they could've caught long before it had spread to her brain. (She passed at 60 and they begin X-ray screening at 50).

Guess what?

She was huge into homeopathic medicine. She took dozens of different tablets, claiming they were all healthy and beneficial. She became incredibly OCD about what kind of foods to eat and didn't trust anything that wasn't organic. She also did a bunch of weird treatments, like "light" therapy, and god knows what else. I watched my mom succumb to cancer in 7 months flat, because she didn't even want to do Chemotherapy and never tried any other options that were available. She also spent probably the last of her money on "CBD oil" claiming that she would "get over" the cancer that way. All of that stemmed from her medical ignorance and distrust of doctors. She was also an anti-vaxxer, believed in aliens, and thought "rocks" carried healing properties.

The point is- its fake. Homeopathy is all bullshit, and purely anecdotal. How you feel about something doesn't help you fight cancer or improve your health. Go to your doctor, get a check up, ask them to check out that weird mole, tell them you have a strange cough, whatever it takes. Go to your medically licensed doctor before its too late. Don't lead yourself down that path- don't be gullible, look into things on your own, then ask a freaking doctor about it. They will gladly answer your questions.


And yes- before any of you weirdo "Doctor bad" people reply about your miracle success stories, or how your loved ones are "beating" cancer with turmeric root or whatever- she did EVERYTHING. It didn't work. End of story.

Some time in summer 2019, I visited my local Walgreens in NJ, looking for ear drop medicine. I had developed very painful swimmer's ear due to all the swimming I do. I find on the shelf various brands of eardrop, some clearly marked "homeopathic". I definitely avoided those and picked up what I believed to be REAL eardrop medicine. I have a question about its efficacy. So I ask the pharmacist on duty.


Good thing I asked the pharmacist, because the pharmacist pointed out that the eardrop brand I had picked up was ALSO homeopathic. I later returned to the shelf to put it back and observed that Walgreens carried NO real eardrop medicine. Only the plain water/homeopathic scamming crap.


I ask the pharmacist about the ingredients: how well they work to relieve ear pain, and I ask if I can get a more concentrated dose.
That's when he pointed out that this brand was homeopathic by saying "all those ingredients would GIVE you an earache".
To my shock & dismay, the pharmacist started rattling off the usual homeopathic bullshit about "some people believe that super dilute doses etc etc" In other words, the pharmacist seemed to be defending this homeopathic crap.


It would be bad if this is what the pharmacist truly believes & that Walgreens had simply chosen a poor employee.

Actually, the like cures like philosophy inherent to homeopathy is the exact same concept that which vaccines work upon. The harm of this sort of thing is that it DOESN'T heal them, it merely applies a placebo affect to them which CAN help with some cases... But not every disease or oddity in the body can be repelled via placebo.
Worse, the few successes that result can cause the people that use these faulty remedies to suggest them to others, which can lead to serious infections and death since a placebo's effects are variable as hell.

TL;DR: Placebos are bad because they inspire confidence that leads to a false sense of security.
It's akin to using a cardboard box as a bunker to hide from a nuclear detonation.
You might somehow survive a nuke within one at a distance, but telling other people to do this instead of finding proper shelter or fleeing the threat is a bad, BAD thing.

So there is PLENTY wrong with allowing this ignorance to spread.
Ignorance and false security kills.

So the working ingredients of homeopathy are attention an mindset? Thought so.

I usually deal with illness (flu, a cold, sore anything) by ignoring it. Not neglecting, but ignoring.

My attitude towards illnesses like that is something like "well, I'm sick, my body will get over it so I don't need to give it any extra attention". Yes, it hurts, but it also hurts if I'm doing something I like.

It works every time. Just because I'm ill doesn't mean I have to act like I'm ill. Your body will respond with feeling better.

That trick works on other levels as well: a well-known trick is to get a pencil, stick it between your teeth so you're forcing your mouth to display a (sort of) smile, and you'll feel happier, if only because you look silly now ;-)
The message your "smiling" mouth is sending to your brain is "look, I'm happy. I'm smiling so clearly I'm happy" and your brain will respond by letting you feel happy, or at least happier than you were.

If you combine ignoring (not neglecting) your illness (and please note I'm NOT talking about the serious stuff like cancer and gangreen and such, please hurry to the hospital if that's the case!) with a placebo of some kind (I like small amounts of whisky, it's tasty and it contains alcohol which is also the main ingredient of over-the-counter homeopathic medicines) you'll be up and about in no time!

Oh, one last thing: there's a difference between ignoring and neglecting.

Say you cut your thumb with a knife. You don't want to neglect that, you want to put a band-aid on it. Then you can ignore it. The band-aid is applied, and there's nothing else you can do about it so you can just as well put your mind to something else.

Same if you paint the floor (or the walls, or whatever). You applied the paint, and now you have two choices: watch it dry (which doesn't do anything but costing you time), or you can ignore it and do something else. The paint will dry either way.

I think homeopathy isn't that great a danger that everyone in this comment section does it make to be. Beeing born in germany I got a lot of homeopathic treatments as a little kid from around the age of 8 to about 16. The reason why it's called an "alternative medicine" is because it's a nice substitute for real medicine. Of course it doesn't help shit, but instead of taking antibiotics which are proven to be really bad on the long run I always took my sugar pills when having a bit of a headache or something minor. It's especially good for kids who hurt themselves while playing outside, you just give them a plaster and a sugar pill and they're happy. I'd never in my whole life come to the conclusion that it's in any way ok to resort to homeopathy when beeing really sick like having fever or something like it, but IMO taking real medicine for every itch you have just isn't the way to go.

And don't ever underestimate the placebo effect on the human mind, especially when it comes to allergies like hay fever. I have hay fever since I can remember, so bad that they acutally told me on a scale from 1 to 10 I was the 11th. So my go to doctor at the age of 13 always used to just write some strange kind of rune behind my right ear with a pen, which is complete nonsense, and I know that. But it helped so much, even a bit more then conventional "cetrizin" which they also gave me. I strongly believe that homeopathy on it's own doesn't cure shit, but thinking it would can help many people to feel better, and in my case, even to completely supress the symptoms caused by allergies.

That said, any parent who doesn't get their kids the treatment they need when they are really sick and need to go to the hospital but resort to homoepathy should not be allowed to raise kids, that is the real danger that comes with a pseudo science like this.

Oh I'm definitely immune to the placebo effect. I learned long ago that I'm not the little engine that could. Whether or not I can do something is not enhanced by having a positive attitude and telling myself I can do it. If I couldn't do it before, I can't do it with a positive attitude, and I'll often find myself saying "Oh, I didn't think I would be able to do that, but I did it anyway". And if I expect a drug to do something, doesn't change whether it does. Which is good, because I'm a consummate pessimist and if I was the little engine that could, because of my negativity, I wouldn't be able to do anything. One reason I would never waste my time with the likes of homeopathy. It would have no effect on me. Pharmaceuticals in general generally have either muted effects in me or they do things other than what I was hoping for or expecting, at best it's kind of like making a wish with an asshole genie who will twist your words. Anti-Vaccination heightens the chance of outbreak through transmission, the placebo effect isn’t always 100% reliable, and the belief the prescription actually works causes misconceptions. Placebos don’t always work and in my opinion for them to be truly be integrated in modern medicine doctors would need to find a way to see if a patient is— and by how much— susceptible to the effect and prescribe accordingly. I view Homeopathy as purely a placebo, fake biology but not fake psychology. Its effect is real, but not in the way that people think it is; and that’s the problem.

This increased faith in the effectiveness of homeopathic treatment, was recorded by 23 institutes under the Central Council for Reasearch in Homeopathy (CCRH).

Homeopathy is being promoted as it is not only safe and effective but also due to its high acceptance through high quality surveys of use of homeopathy. Attempts are also being made to dispel the notion in the minds of the people, that homeopathy is a pseudoscience. The conclusion of most comprehensive systematic reviews of studies based on classical homoeopathy has concluded that it has a positive and specific effect greater than placebo alone. Four systematic reviews and meta-analysis of homeopathy for all conditions, were published in international peer reviewed journals. Of these, three covered hundreds of clinical trials, and reached a positive conclusion that there is evidence that homeopathy is clinically effective. Moreover, the review of basic research on highly diluted homeopathic medicines found 98 replicated experiments, over 70% of replications were positive.

There is evidence that homoeopathy is beneficial and not merely a placebo. 'Scientific Framework of Homoeopathy- Evidence Based Homeopathy' consists of research worldwide and 'Homoeopathy -Science of Gentle healing' focused to Research in India has enlisted hundreds of scientific trials including basic research showing strong evidence towards the beneficial role of homoeopathy. I think homeopathy is hogwash, but if you want to blame someone for the appeal of homeopathy, then yes, you definitely have include conventional medicine, especially when conventional medicine goes wrong. Generic scenario:

Patient has infection.
Patient sees doctor, doctor prescribes antibiotics.
Patient has horrible reaction to antibiotics and tells the doctor.
Doctor insists the antibiotics can't be the cause (but never looks up the warnings to make sure).
Patient continues drug--patient becomes more ill.
Without permission, patient stops drug.
Infection gone, but patient still feels sick from drug reaction and sees doctor.
Doctor gets irritated, again insisting drug can't be the cause, and patient is left confused and helpless.
Patient seeks out alternative help, like a homeopathic doctor.
This doctor believes patient about the drug, does research and finds out that the drug has warnings about all the symptoms the patient is experiencing.
Patient not only feels believed, but now knows what really happened.
Even if the homeopathic doctor's treatment doesn't help, the patient knowing what happened and being believed is enough. Patient no longer trusts conventional medicine.

As someone who works in the hospital industry I can give another reason why homeopathy has caught on so much. Hospitals cost too much and have little incentive to find ways to cut costs. Many medical techniques such as x-rays are proven and useful, though the technology is so old at this point the actual cost of the device and treatment is highly questionable. Then you have the medical fields like Multiple Sclerosis and it's associated symptoms where doctors basically prey upon desperate people selling them snake oil. If you have optic neuritis for example you could be charged $2500 a visitation to sit in a machine with the advanced technology of flashing LED lights. At some point somebody will try to sell you Interferon, or you will given repeated dangerous doses of prednisone(don't do this). For some patients none of this helps, and its questionable to me whether the ones that do get better were helped by their treatments at all. I doubt whether homeopathic medicine does anything either but at least it won't cause more damage and be dramatically cheaper. In conclusion it is the medical industry's unethical practices that give rise to alternative medicine. It is not an efficient machine it is a bureaucracy.

Stating that modern medicine is a machine and that we can learn something from homeopathic clinics is all well and good, but until insurance companies reimburse physicians for sick/wellness visits beyond the times allotted now, then this really doesn't fix the problems highlighted.  This is not a new idea anyway; most clinicians would spend more time with patients if they weren't limited by documentation, billing, and the tremendous shortage of doctors to meet the demands.  Homeopathy also unjustly charges patients for "remedies" that have no clear benefit beyond placebo compared to randomized, controlled, double-blinded studies published in peer-reviewed journals.  Some preparations can even cause harm, such as in a patient on multiple medications that experiences a drug-drug interaction.  The fact that there is no regulation for snake oils and their salesmen is the real problem in medicine.

That bit about doctors giving their patients a little extra attention is absolutely something that needs to improve. I am a trans girl, and it took me a full year to actually get on the right hormone therapy. I saw 3 different doctors before I found my current one, and every one of them seemed like they just wanted to shove their own opinions down my throat, and they refused to acknowledge any of my concerns or the medical literature I had brought in about the treatment. I was on the wrong dosage for a long time (which wreaks havoc on your mind and body, and can literally disintegrate your bones), I never got follow-up calls when they scheduled them, and I even got scolded and yelled at for talking about going to a new doctor. After all that shit, I was dangerously close to just buying the medicine illegally and doing it myself. Thankfully, my current doctor is very nice to me. I did most of the talking at my first appointment, and she asked me all about my history with hormone therapy, and even some stuff like whether I'd gotten electrolysis -- and no one else had ever shown that amount of care. She even put me on the exact medicine I wanted, and her office actually calls back to see if my insurance is giving me trouble.

Point is, bedside manner is important. I'd be shooting up estrogen from shady sources right now if my current doctor had been just as rude and counterproductive as the others.

It seems, as if no one here is in favour of it, and thats probably because those who do are already used to being offended and would watch a video like this very rarely. I see, this is supporting you saying that they are naive, stupid, ignorant or whatever, but I would like to tell you something:

I was brought up without vaccinations (well, i had one or two, but than I had a very bad reaction to one of it and the doctor my mom took me too did nothing to ease it, she was more like: let's see if she makes it through the weekend) and basically just homeopathy (which mostly did me good). But might seem surprising I wanted to be a doctor since a very young age, and using and believing in homeopathy has not affected my interest and trust in modern medicine. I understand that its effects are proven and I strongly trust science. I am fascinated by the power of modern medicine, I am really pro-medicine. But still, I would use homeopathy for some things. For example, if you have a skin issue, it might have a psychosomatic reason (and that's real science! ;) ). Everyone would appreciate applying cortisone-lotion on it to ease the symptom, but I would go to my homeopath (who is a "real doctor" as well) to help me deal with the reason of it, hoping that it doesn't return. Yes, I could accept that I have neurodermatitis or something and I have it forever, BUT homeopathy holds the chance that it might never return.

So, maybe you yourself could be less ignorant and acknowledge that some people, in their despair or based on their experience, decide to use homeopathy; either because regular medicine can't help them or because they have lost their trust in that and still want to do something.

potentization history-

Hahnemanns' early writings frequently advise using small doses of medicines, but say nothing about potencies or potentization. Examples of the references to low doses occur in the article published in Hufelands Journal in 1796 announcing the similia principle, and in the first edition of the Organon published in 1810 (para. 247). His requirement at this stage is simply that the amount of medicine used should be the smallest possible to produce the required therapeutic effect. Both Haehl's biography of Hahnemann and the writings of Hahnemann himself imply that his aim in this was the reduction of the toxic effects from overdosing with medicines for which he frequently criticized other prescribers. This intention appears to have directed Hahnemann's work for several years. A development of his theories and practice became evident about six to eight years later. In 1812 he is recorded as using Arnica 6c and Nux vomica 9c for an epidemic of intermittent fever. Two years later, we are now up to 1814, an article published by Hahnemann on the treatment of typhus fever shows a further and notable change in his developing ideas about such microdoses. Here he states that the therapeutic effects of medicines are not directly related to increasing doses, but that conversely greater benefits can be obtained when they are used in diluted or refined states. This means that even at this relatively early stage in his work, only 4 years after the publication of the first edition of the Organon, Hahnemann states that low doses of medicine are not only less toxic than the higher doses for which he has often castigated his colleagues, but they are also more effective therapeutically. Two closely related discoveries appear to have led him to this statement. One was the improved therapeutic effects of reducing the dosage of previously used medicines. The other finding was that substances such as salt or lycopodium, not previously identified as medicines, became therapeutically active when used in microdoses. After such observations Hahnemann increasingly referred to these minute doses of medicinal agents as 'power developments' or 'potencies', implying the therapeutic potential that he had found was enhanced or released by their reduction.

Let’s take a journey through time. DHMIS

It is in the issue of potentisation that mainstream biomedical thought has the greatest difficulty accepting homeopathy as a valid therapeutic system. According to homeopathic principles, remedies with the greatest dilutions have the greatest therapeutic effect, despite the virtual absence of molecules (based on Avogadro’s number) in the remedy.

SO READ IT -

Any wave-like phenomena can create an interference pattern, including light and radio waves. Because laser light is an extremely pure, coherent form of light, it is especially good at creating interference patterns. It provides, in essence, the perfect pebble and the perfect pond. As a result, it wasn’t until the invention of the laser that holograms, as we know them today, became possible. A hologram is produced when a single laser light is split into two separate beams. The first beam is bounced off the object to be photographed. Then the second beam is allowed to collide with the reflected tight of the first. When this happens they create an interference pattern which is then recorded on a piece of film. The threedimensionality of such images is often eerily convincing. You can actually walk around a holographic projection and view it from different angles as you would a real object.

Similarly, when a remedy is made, the dilutions receive succussions, which create interference patterns. As we know frrom holograms, the part always contains the whole. Thus, we see that the entire nature of the original substance is recreated in the potency and this explains the range of action of the homoeopathic remedy in a simple and easily understandable way. Hahnemann did not know about holograms, but his intuitive understanding of the nature of the potencies gave him a means to describe them in terms we can still understand today.

The “whole in every part” nature of a hologram certainly seems to explain how so much of the visual cortex can be removed without affecting the ability to perform visual tasks. If the brain is processing images by employing some kind of internal hologram, even a very small piece of the hologram can still reconstruct the whole of what the eyes are seeing. It also explains the lack of any one-to-one correspondence between the external world and the brain’s electrical activity. The point to keep in mind is the electrical activity of the brain. In the same way as the brain has electrical activity, the remedy displays an electromagnetic wave, which is precisely what is passed on from potency to potency, as I have explained in my previous article on the nano-phase potency production. This wave, when undergoing succussion, naturally produces interference waves, which in turn display the entirety of the original substance, because the electron which has been rubbed off the molecules, carries a negative charge, which contains in essence all the properties of the original substance.

Thus, when a potency is made by trituration – and even when a tincture is diluted and succussed without trituration preceding this process – the electromagnetic wave, created by either trituration or succussion is the “energy” that creates the interference waves which in turn produce the holographic “image” of the original substance.

In the homoeopathic potency, we discover a similar “threedimensionality” to the hologram, in that the entire original substance, with all its properties, is present in the potencies. It is not so much that we can “walk around it”, but in the proving, all the properties will come to the fore, some more prominent than others, all the while displaying the entirety of those original properties. Thus, the remedy Arsenicum album will display all the properties caused by poisoning with Arsenic in the symptom picture, although the dose is so small, that actual poisoning does not take place. This “threedimensionality” of the properties of Arsenic is without any doubt present and shows in the totality of all the provers the entire range of action of the original poisonous substance “holographically”.

The fact that a single drop of each potency will produce the entire pattern in the next potency – albeit in weaker form when not succussed – and the fact that succussion will augment that threedimensional picture into a recognisable reaction when taken sufficiently often by a prover, shows that there is a holographic property in homoeopathic potencies. Of this there cannot be any doubt, since the entire pattern of symptoms can be reproduced by a proving in any potency.

Research conducted by Pribram revealed that if he removed as much as 98 percent of the part of the brain that receives and interprets what the eye sees, he found it could still perform tasks requiring complex visual skills. Similarly, if 98% of the original substance has been removed by dilution, we find it is still capable of displying all the complexity of the original substance.

The brilliant Hungarian-born physicist and mathematician John von Neumann once calculated that over the course of the average human lifetime, the brain stores something on the order of 2.8 X 1020 (280,000,000,000,000,000,000) bits of information. This is a staggering amount of information, to say the least. In the same way, the remedy can store information in the potencies that lies in an order of magnitude far surpassing that of Von Neumann's calculations for the brain, which frankly speaking is in my opinion but a tiny fraction of what the brain is capable to store.

The holographic idea offers a further analogy for the associative tendencies of memory. And it also gives rise to the notion of the memory of water, which is capable of storing information. Although in my understanding water does not possess a “memory”, but instead is an information storage device much like a RW-CD – meaning the information can both be stored and wiped or replaced by other information – the analogy is apt enough. Since the remedy is a holographic image of the original substance, the water must be able to store that information in the form of electromagnetic wave interference patterns, which have been augmented or amplified by the process of succussion. In fact, succussion is the creation of interference patterns.

If you look at a hologram it seems to have extension in space, but if you pass your hand through it you will discover there is nothing there. Despite what your senses tell you, no instrument will pick up the presence of any abnormal energy or substance where the hologram appears to be hovering. This is because a hologram is a virtual image, an image that appears to be where it is not, and possesses no more extension in space than does the three-dimensional image you see of yourself when you look in a mirror. Just as the image in the mirror is located in the silvering on the mirror’s back surface, the actual location of a hologram is always in the photographic emulsion on the surface of the film recording it.


Similarly, the energy of the remedy cannot be detected by means of instruments of classical physics, because it is not detectable by such means. As in the wave-particle physics of quantum mechanics we can either detect the wave or the particle. Dependent on what the observer wants to see, so in a hologram, we see only an image when the light of a laser beam strikes it at the right angle. Similarly, in detecting the energy pattern of a remedy, we can use several means, such as piezo-electric measurements, MRI and Raman Laser Spectography, but these means tell us that there is something there, which is only “visible” when the right “beam” has been directed at it, of which RLS is the one most resembling the visibility of the hologram.

This also explains the inability of the skeptics to perceive the reality of the homoeopathic potencies, because they refuse to “look” at them and so for them, these phenomena cannot have any real existence. Rooted in classical physics, they cannot comprehend that anything exists outside the “physical reality” of Newtonian concepts. Since they cannot be forced to look at something they perceive mentally as not having any existence, their limited and narrow worldview cannot comprehend anything beyond classical physics. They have not yet graduated to the “higher thinking” of quantum physics and thus we should actually pity the poor sods. As always, I stoically accept my continuing role as the voice in the crowd that bravely notes these “emperors” have no clothes.

One startling discovery made by quantum physicists is that if you break matter into smaller and smaller pieces you eventually reach a point where those pieces—electrons, protons, and so on—no longer possess the traits of objects. For example, most of us tend to think of an electron as a tiny sphere or a BB whizzing around, but nothing could be further from the truth. Although an electron can sometimes behave as if it were a compact little particle, physicists have found that it literally possesses no dimension. Thus, homoeopathic potencies, in which electromagnetic energy is passed from potency to potency, no dimensional properties exist, although it has been found that in some potencies there exist still submolecular “particles”, which seem to behave just like the electron and are only “visible as particles” when we direct our attention to them. This is difficult for most of us to imagine because everything at our own level of existence possesses dimension. And yet if you try to measure the width of an electron, you will discover it’s an impossible task. An electron is simply not an object as we know it.

Well, in a way, water does have some kind of effect from it's surroundings. An interesting set of experiments measured this via crystalization. To put it in simple terms, the pattern of crystalization was predictably repeatable which is of course the basis of a genuine scientific experiment. That's not to say the explanation given in homeopathy is neccessarily correct. There must be a limit, or else the counter argument made in this video would certainly be a problem, but if I know anything for sure it's this: no generation in human history has ever been completely correct about anything. Every so often people learn something new and civilization advances.

If you want an analogy, imagine how one might have explained electricity in the past. It's something we can see, and measure, but isn't it weird how it all works? If what we think of as Magick was an all pervasive and present force in this world it would be regarded the same way we regard electricity without any additional thought because at it's simplest when people don't understand something it's either magick or a hoax.

Homeopathy is a very pure concept.  Pure in the sense that it is derived, conducted, and supported by unfettered expression of human cognitive flaws.  It is the medicine of intuition.  The medicine we would all be reduced to relying upon if we abandoned an intellectual pursuit of reason and science.  It is what you get when you rely upon that which SEEMS true or FEELS right rather than what is true and right.  Because our brains fundamentally work by associating stimuli, it naturally requires much less mental effort to conclude that "like cures like".  Add that together with the placebo effect and confirmation bias, essentialism, the desire for the world to be simple, and trusting the personal testimonials of those around you, dilute it 100x, bang it on the table and bingo you've got homeopathy!
