Okay, so probably this'll get lost in the comments but I want to share one perspective as there is one other aspect that gets a bit overlooked here IMHO.

Disclaimer: I don't personally subscribe to homeopathy at all. Just sharing a perspective.

Modern drugs, while effective, are quite invasive and not without their drawbacks. They all come with risks and side-effects that take their own toll on the body and can in fact be very dangerous. Such complications can be hard to predict as different people will have different sensitivities to various drugs. Not to mention it is possible to be allergic to certain types of drugs with possibly fatal results.
That's a major attracting factor to homeopathy that is not being mentioned here, the lack of such risks. This is especially attractive to people that have had negative experiences with modern medicine (such as severe or unpredicted side effects, drug poisoning, allergies, you name it).

My mother for instance suffered from drug poisoning at one point in the 70s and has since lost a lot of trust in modern medicine (though medicine has probably come a long way since the 70s). She appears to have a high sensitivity to many drugs, as do her children to an extent. She is luckily not at all one for the stupidly expensive homeopathic stuff but yes there's a lot of the bach flower remedies and arnica montana going around. She isn't crazy, in the rare occassion that she has a really serious illness then she'll use regular drugs. But she'll always try homeopathy first because modern medicine does truthfully mess with her system a bit more than it normally should.

While I wouldn't personally do it that way (I don't believe homeopathy works beyond the placebo-effect, in which case you could probably find something cheaper), I think it's fairly sensible to try a placebo before trying something that has the potential to mess with your system (in not directly life threatening cases).

Let me preface this comment by saying that I am a user of homeopathic medicine. However, I don’t doubt that the scientific evidence shown in this video is true. I just want to share my experience with homeopathy and how much it has helped me.

1. Food intolerance evaluation.
While not everybody believes in the validity of the food intolerance evaluation, I went in to try it after visiting numerous doctors about awful, persistent migraines. It concluded that I have an intolerance to all fruits, exempting melons and tomatoes. Now, I only have a brief understanding of the science of how this works, so I’m not even going to bother trying to explain it, as I’ll probably say something horribly contradictory to what my doctor had told me. The interesting thing I experienced was that as soon as I cut these foods out of my diet, my migraines began to disappear. I don’t really think it’s as a result of the placebo effect, mostly because I went from having migraines every day, to not having them at all. I could be wrong though.
2. SIBO test.
For years I had struggled with awful digestive issues, making it feel like my intestines were on fire sometimes when I would be using the bathroom. After visiting my main practitioner, he just told me “oh, you have IBS, and there’s no cure so you’ll just have to try one of these diets and then MAYBE it will go away.”
This, no doubt, made me very frustrated. So I contacted my N.D about what I could do to solve this. She provided a breath test for me which could be send in to test for Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth(SIBO). After I completed this test, it was then sent I to a lab where it was tested for the amount of hydrogen and methane within the test tubes (in ppm). Now, while this test is still in its infancy, it did prove to me that there was an excess of hydrogen, and thus I most likely had SIBO. This made it possible for me to obtain an antibiotic through my main practitioner, which, is in fact not naturalpathic medicine.
I wasn’t really trying to disprove this video or the scientific research behind it in any way. I just wanted to explain how it has helped me, and how sometimes it can be a good way to get the medicine you need through tests that aren’t even administered in western medicine.
If anybody has any thoughts or info on this, please let me know and I’d be glad to discuss them.

You’ve completely misrepresented this whole topic. Are you being funded by the petrochemical/pharmaceutical industry?

For starters, 89% of newly developed pharmaceutical drugs are direct copies of naturally occurring compounds (they need to use synthetic copies to increase profitability ie it’s illegal to patent naturally occurring compounds, and people won’t buy drugs for thousands of dollars if they can grow a safer and more effective version for a couple of bucks at home). And on that point you also deliberately mislead people into thinking that the decentralised “homeopathy industry” (aka people who grow plants) is part of the centralised pharmaceutical industry (this is a complete lie) and is worth a few billion dollars globally, and while that monetary figure may even be accurate, you fail to point out that the multi-trillion dollar pharmaceutical industry is highly centralised and is part of the multi-multi-trillion dollar petrochemical industry (which again views these natural compounds as a massive threat to their extremely profitable pharmaceutical industry, for the reasons I outlined previously).

So as well as overlooking these glaringly obvious FACTS, you have also incorrectly defined what homeopathy is. Homeopathy (which has been practiced for literally all of human history, not a couple of hundred years like you erroneously claim in the video) is nothing to do with using compounds that cause symptoms to treat symptoms, that’s industry-funded disinformation, it just means “the same” (homeo) “pathy” (way) because all life on earth is made of the same compounds we are. That’s why natural compounds like apple cider vinegar have amazing antibacterial, antiviral and antifungal properties. This is largely being attributed to a whole new class of naturally occurring chemicals in plants that have recently been discovered called “phytonutrients”, which are basically natural/plant based compounds that protect plants in the wild from disease, fungus, bacteria etc. It’s now scientifically established that our human immune systems actually utilise these compounds at a cellular level and are essential for maintaining a functional immune system. So the old phrases “an apple a day keeps the doctor away” and why eating fruits and vegetables makes you healthier and more resistant to disease makes a lot more sense now.

Lets aproach the topic mathematically. There is a homeopathic ,,medicine" used fot treating influenza, that has a solution from a duck's liver in it, at a potentization rate of 200C. Now, some context. The human body, on average, contains about 0.00063 moles of Arsenic, and 0.0000087 moles of Radium. Two elements that are incredibly toxic, but on this small of a scale, they dont cause any trouble, they can barely be noticed. By contrast, in this medicine, there is aproximately 0.0000000000000000000000000000000000000000000012 moles of duck liver. Which means, that in a mole of the medicine, there is not a SINGLE ATOM of the stuff left in there.
So yes, you are essentially taking glorified sugar cubes you buy for 20 dollars and expecting it to cure you. Sure there is the placebo effect, but dont try and tell me that something that has litterally nothing of the curative substance left can cure you of anything.
(And lets not even mention the fact that the reason they use duck liver is because of a 19th century discovery, that spotted bacteria in the duck's liver, and the bacteria were named the cause of influenza. Since then it has been proven that a duck's liver doesnt contain this bacteria and said bacteria is also not responsible for influenza.)
I rest my case.

So people now associate homeopathy with anything that does not subscribe to 'western' medical methods, or simply think it is synonymous with 'natural' or 'herbal'. They tend not to associate it with 'like cures like' or dilution. Many herbal medicines actually do have modest effects and people tend to label that success on homeopathy. That's my anecdote with people who love homeopathy anyway. They don't actually know they aren't describing homeopathy at all. Hell, some products are even described as homeopathic and 'concentrated' extract of some or other herb.

Actually, I'd express some doubts about modern medicine's "efficiency". (not treating someone just means they go to another doctor and then another and then another and then another and so on endlessly - it would be far MORE efficient to help them the first time than to put them through ten office visits and two hospitalizations in a single year without anyone lifting a finger to help - sadly, speaking from experience here). This can leave patients feeling alienated and desperate for answers or help from ANY source, no matter how crazy or stupid. And the "get the patient to come in for unneccessary office visits" is a frequent scam run almost universally in the medical field. Need your prescription refilled? Oh, you've been on it for years and have no problems with it and your life depends on it? Too bad. You need an office visit for a refill anyway (because the doctors have to "make their money", and they often admit this straight out). Holding vital medicines hostage, lack of diagnostics skills outside of invasive and sometimes INCREDIBLY damaging medical proceedures (often being unneccessary, as well), and the general lack of any form of compassion, empathy, or even basic responcible care from physicians weakens trust in their services, as do excessive bills and underhanded debt collection techniques (such as holding medicines or medical records hostage for payment). Add to that the fact that doctors frequently falsify medical records to cover their butts when they act like idiots, and a LOT of people start losing faith in them and looking elsewhere. If people felt their doctor cared and that they could trust them to understand their patient's needs and be helpful and compassionate, there would be far fewer flocking to snake oil salesmen like these homeopaths. The simple fact is that there's just no way to get good medical treatment for certain illnesses, in America at least.

And I speak from a MOUNTAIN of experience (over a decade of experience being a medical lab rat... in 7 different states...). To give you just one example, the Mayo Clinic in MN diagnosed chest pains that stab in time with one's pulse, cause weakness in the arms and legs, coldness, difficulty breathing, and are only made better by laying down or going to sleep as... heartburn (with a side order of supposed "panic attacks", though I've never had a panic attack in my life and the chest pains, if anything, make me too tired to feel anything but calm and very very sleepy). They patronizingly responded that "Well, you don't want it to be a heart problem", and then added that I was just a women (and all women are overly emotional) so I must be having panic attacks (because all women do, apparently). Nope, no sexism here... (Oh, and the only thing they did to investigate the chest pains was order a pap smear... on a virgin... If you can explain that one, you are smarter than me...) But that's just one horror story. I've entered an ER writhing in pain and left with permanent nerve damage from their treatment (which put my life in danger). I've been drugged up with huge doses of morphine and rushed hundreds of miles to a bigger hospital, only to have them refuse to treat me (because of a false piece of information inserted into my medical records by a well-meaning but misguided doctor I'd seen before the incident). I've had doctors withold vital anti-seizure drugs to extort on office visit from me, without any consideration of the fact that I can't drive or walk and lived over 30 miles away. How was I supposed to get there? It's not like there's public transit in the US! Had I not stockpiled enough medicine to last me until I could convince a doctor to write a prescription, I could have died, and my doctor didn't care at all.

TL;DR - Callous, abusive behavior by physicians undermines trust in them, not homeopathy. The simple fact is that homeopathy is just riding the coattails of a problem the doctors THEMSELVES created with their so-called "efficiency", something that leaves many patients suffering needlessly just so doctors and hospitals can line their greedy pockets.
The second one, mostly. Selling people overpriced placebo, especially when a more effective real treatment isn't being sought as a result, is health endangering fraud.

Effect Placebo is by-product of our brain activity. Animals don't can "believe" in good, because there’s no evidence whatsoever that animals can benefit from, or even experience, placebo effects.  

There is a good body of research that demonstrates that human contact has measurable effects on animals.  For example, petting by humans reduces heart rates in dogs and horses and causes major vascular changes in dogs. Gentle handling increases productivity in dairy heifers and increases reproductive efficiency in sows. Thus, it is plausible that human-animal contact might play an important role in the observed responses to therapeutic interventions.  To take an “alternative” example, it has been shown that a single acupuncture treatment is as effective as petting a horse, when it comes to relief of signs of chronic airway disease; that is, there’s no demonstrable effect of acupuncture beyond simple handling. On the other hand, handling may also be stressful to animals, so responses to handling may not necessarily be beneficial.  Still, there’s no question that human contact can invoke responses from animals and animals may behave quite differently when they are not being observed; those shouldn’t be confused with placebo-effects, however.

Gross, WB.  "The benefits of tender loving care"
Heinsworth, PH, Brand, A, Willems, PJ.  "The behavioral response of sows to the presence of human beings and their productivity". 
Wilson, DV, Berney, CE, Peroni, DL, et al.  "The effects of a single acupuncture treatment in horses with severe recurrent airway obstruction".

I just want to preface my comment by saying that I majored in chemistry, hell I make videos about it, so if that makes you think that my thoughts on homeopathy invalid somehow... Well this is your chance to just keep scrolling.


That out of the way, I have no care if people want to use homeopathy in conjunction with regular, working meds. If you are suffering from terminal cancer and feel like rubbing some mint oil on the nape of your neck, go right ahead.

That said, just because it is natural doesn't mean it is good. Your body can't tell the difference between natural limonene, or synthetic limonene, because they are the same. A chemical is always the same regardless of it's source, the impurities are what is important. And when you make a drug in a lab it is more pure than nature.

Let's talk about a little thing that I got to do in my organic chemistry class, making asprin. Asprin, or acetyl salicylic acid, was made by mixing acetic acid with salicylic acid. Well salicylic acid is found in the back of Willow trees, native Americans would gnaw on them to relieve pain. However there is a lot of problems with doing that now, side effects and what not. While you might think that asprin is evil because it's not natural... Well that's silly, it's just a chemical that is blocking some pain receiver sights from triggering.

You usually do such a good job, Kurzgesagt, but you had a big flaw in this one. You spread a lot of misinformation about placebos in this video. The placebo effect in science means all the variables that skew the data. Examples of this are statistical anomalies or biased reporting. Contrary to common misconceptions we do not have a placebo wing in tests to account for the power of belief, but to account for the participants biases as well as extraneous factors that may not have been accounted for in the test. A common example of placebo is pain reduction. Pain is a partly subjective measurement and is difficult to measured objectively, so it is usually measured in patient reporting. Thing is, patients have a subconscious expectation that their treatment should have an effect and have a tendency to exaggerate their reports in that direction even if they feel just as hurt. This is what placebo means. It does not mean wish power or the power of belief. There are no experiments that show placebo to actually have any physical effects other than maybe the personal perception of pain or minor and temporary effects on stress or muscle tension as would be expected of a mental state. Placebo does not heal. That is a myth that you are propagating.

Homeopathy means that if your extract had a (rather ridiculous) concentration of 1M, in your 30C you decreased the concentration down to a likelyhood. Yes, a likelyhood, because 1L of a 1M solution contains 6*10^23 molecules which you diluted down by the factor of 10^60, resulting in a solution where you find one single molecule with a likelyhood of a whopping 6*10^-35 %. And this you divide by the amount of globuli you can make from 1L of solution.

The image of patients being labeled on a conveyor belt is poetically accurate for emergency medicine where I work. I'm employed in Australia and the hospitals in our state follow a 4 hour rule - a patient should be reviewed by a doctor and ready to leave the emergency department within 4 hours. If you spend longer, the NUM starts to breathe down your neck and hurry you along. As a result we're all constantly working, racing through a patient's preliminary diagnosis so we determine ASAP whether the patient should stay in hospital and under which discipline - which is rather demoralising because some patients do require us spending extra time to get things right.

I should be clear that I don't have a better solution. This type of conveyor belt medicine is indeed very time-efficient and that quality is vital in a place where lives can slip away in a matter of minutes. I've been living with a chronic illness (for over 25 years, now), that - until recently - was pretty much ignored or even derided by many people in the medical establishment. This was despite a massive amount of evidence (that's currently growing at near exponential rates) showing that:
• It is a REAL physical disease & the people who have it are NOT hypochondriacs or fakers;
• It has a genetic component (& can definitely run in families);
• It has identifiable diagnostic criteria including abnormalities that can be seen in blood tests & distinctively on fMRI scans;
• It's not a psychological condition (though being chronically ill for a very long time, is likely - of course - to cause Clinical Depression in some people);
• People with this disease were NOT seeking drugs to get high, but living with extraordinary levels of excruciating (& exhausting) Neuropathic Pain with few alternatives for relief.

Over the years, I've been understandably desperate to find both answers about the condition & a cure (or even just a viable treatment for the symptoms - especially the Pain). This search has inevitably led me to try damn near anything or anyone - even if only to treat the symptoms.

Despite all of that, I was never remotely interested in Homeopathy. In fact I've found it both ludicrous & profoundly disgusting. That it uses plant extracts should make it a plausible alternative (at least for some conditions), but unfortunately the whole regime of dilution & "the memory of water" utter nonsense, ruins it completely.

It's easy to understand how people could become interested by it's promotion as a safe & healthy alternative to mainstream medications - especially those ones with unpleasant side-effects. But it is fraud & quackery, and should be treated as criminal where it is used exclusively (& instead of a real drug, or treatment) in life & death situations. It can't cure cancer & anyone saying that it can, should be sent to prison.


Unfortunately, it isn't alone in being a popular medical treatment, with other nonsensical & pseudo-scientific 'alternative therapies' - such as the bizarre Chiropractic (which is responsible for multiple deaths & injuries each year) - being part of a booming business.Only through educating people in a non-confrontational way, can we move back to evidence based practice & get the best possible result for everybody.

I went through 20-30 of them and eventually did find one that indeed felt warm to the touch... I gave it to my mother to see if she could feel it too, which she did not, but it still felt warm to me when I got it back...

I wish I could run into this again as an adult, so I could run a double blind experiment on it...

I feel like a lot of people are getting lost in the rage for/against homeopathy and missing the real meaty point brought up in this video: A more personal approach, especially in the case of chronic disease, could potentially improve outcomes. In an ideal world doctors would also act as therapists, giving each patient the attention they feel they need. The placebo effect means patients who feel like they are truly cared for and understood can and will get better results.

I say this as somebody from a family plagued by easy to misdiagnose and difficult to fully treat chronic illness. My father once passed out in a doctors office from internal bleeding while the doctor was explaining he thought there was nothing wrong with him. My mother, who has been working in medical research for her entire career, spent two years and thousands of dollars pursuing all kinds of quack medicine, like chelation therapy and antivirals that damaged her kidneys and livers, because her neurologist thought her early MSA symptoms were psychosomatic. Legitimately sick people end up victims of the alternative medicine industry because they're desperate, not because they're stupid.

You’re burying the lead. The “placebo effect” is well-documented evidence that people can activate their own body’s healing ability through intention alone. “Science” still does not know how this happens on a biochemical level. All we know is that it does, over and over—but it’s also not reliable & is affected by many variables that are hard to control for. This is the exact same case for homeopathy. Elaborate "proofs" that homeopathy can't work on the chemical level are pointless. Nobody ever said it worked on a chemical level. It works by the same unknown-to-science mechanism that the placebo effect works by. Practitioners of energy medicine study, refine, and develop methodologies to increase that effect—the body’s ability to heal itself—and homepathy is one of them.

It’s hard to prove that they are more effective than the “vanilla placebo” effect in any scientifically “valid” way because in a study of how intention affects healing, the intention of the researchers and subjects affect the study itself. And the intention of researchers is generally to look for a chemical effect, and there is no chemical effect, so they don’t find one. They get exactly what they are looking for: a result that fits their worldview. (If you are arguing that pets & kids & patients get better because the doctor believes they will, you also have to accept that subjects in a study may not show any effect because the researchers do not believe it’s possible for there to be any effect.)

In essence, it’s very hard to scientifically show the effect of intention on health because humans always have intentions and they are not objectively measurable. So we have no way to reliably measure if imbuing water with the healing essence of a plant through this process increases the ability of that water to activate healing, if that water is always administered through a scientific model by people who believe only chemical effects are real. (The healing essence of a plant can be thought of as that plant’s “intention” — only humans as far as we know can will their intention, everything else is just intending to be what it is, on an energetic level). So essentially this video only proves that homeopathy is not chemical medicine (but nobody said it was), and that science can’t prove it works (but that’s obvious if you understand that science can’t measure energy medicine in general because it has no way to neutralize the intention effect).

Re: Homeopathy, and alternative medicine in general, my GP has taken an interesting stance that I think would benefit people. When it comes to some things it's important to listen to your doctor, but if the goal is to relieve symptoms and not related to curing a disease or preventing harm, it doesn't matter if it works because of science or because you believe it will.

She would not encourage anyone to not get vaccinated or avoid an ER or GP, but if you have pain, or you want to stop sniffling, it doesn't really matter how you feel better since the goal of the treatment simply is to feel better.


She finds it very important to work with alternative medicine because that's how you make sure the people who want this path have access to both. A doctor who tells you your homoeopathic headache cure is bogus while it doesn't harm anyone and works as well as Tylenol would for the most important goal, making you feel better, is going to have a harder time convincing you to get treatment when an important thing comes around. Doctors antagonizing patients for things they don't have to means they're less receptive to the things that really are important, like vaccines or cancer treatment.
The doctors that I've seen who are most able to get people against western medicine to accept certain important pieces of it are doctors who give the patient as much as is safe to what the patient is comfortable with, I know multiple offices that have a natropathic doctor working with a GP so that people who dont feel safe with a GP can still get adequate treatment. We need to acknowledge that yelling at people that they're stupid won't make them change their minds and find a better way to reach them.

Only had 1 experience with homeopathy
A while ago, after suffering for 2 years with really bad eczema - I'd tried a lot of creams prescribed by doctors, moisturisers etc. I was given steroid cream but this only helped my eczema while I was using it and when I stopped it would come back even worse. So my dad decided to take me to a homeopath. He described what it did and they talked etc (couldn't understand most of it as it my 2nd Lang that they talked in) and after a while he gave me a 2 lots of pills, 1 to take once a week and to take the other 4 times a day.
Tbh at the time I thought wow this new medication might actually help me (again, I didnt know what exactly homeopathy was I'd only heard of it and in my mind it was a reliable type of medicine, then I googled it when I got home and found out that there's a lot of controversy behind it and was basically all shambles, which disappointed me quite a bit
So fast forward, I start taking the pills, the actual pills tasted of sugar so they were like free sweets tbh, but initially I thought they were a waste of money and there's no way they'd work.
Id noticed whenever I took the first pill (once a week) my skin would flare up immensely like never before (there was 1 day where my whole face looked swollen and I didn't even want to go school because it was so painful to even touch my eyes) but I noticed a few days after these flare ups my skin would become clearer than before (as it was normally very red, painful and itchy). A few weeks later (after the course) I was pretty much completely eczema free and it wasn't until after that I realized what the homeopath said was true, after taking the pills I woud flare up a bit and it would get better. I don't think it was the placebo effect (as I believed the steroid creams were working but my eczema would come back after stopping, and because I spent most of the time eating the pills thinking there's no way in hell this little sugar pill will do anything)

So, whether the pill actually helped me or not, I don't know but that was my first and only experience with homeopathy so I'm skeptical to believe homeopathy is complete bs (which it does sound like, logically). Since then (this was 7 months ago) my eczema has gone up and down but never as bad as it used to be (my face, arms, neck, back and legs were constantly red/itchy) however it has recently been flaring a bit more so I am thinking of going back for another course

Thank you for this important video.  Homeopathy should have been put to rest back in 1988, when Benveniste, a French immunologist, published an article in Nature in which his studies appeared to demonstrate that anti-IgE antibody was still capable of causing human basophil degranulation in vitro even when diluted down lower than Avogadro's number (i.e., greater than 6.02 times 10 to the 23rd power dilution, which guaranteed that no molecules of the anti-IgE could remain in the culture medium).  He argued that the water retained the memory of the anti-IgE.  I remember the scientific community being outraged that this paper made it past the peer-review process in Nature and their reputation took a huge hit.  An independent committee was formed (that included James Randi, who was famous for debunking Uri Geller) and they investigated the lab and found that the results could not be reproduced.  But Benveniste refused to withdraw the article.

It should not be secret that the reason why placebo works most of the time, is because mentality has a HUGE impact on your health... It is like having will - " I aint gonna get out of this bed " and it gets to you so much that you spend more time there than you would if you actually fought it with spirit " This is not gonna get me this easily " Boom you feel better. Pills do not really help in any way majority of times because there is no purely specific cure for one thing - it always includes different ingredients.

For example - there is no such a thing as " CURE FOR HEADACHE " there are pills against pain... it simply soothes the pain and essentially the pain goes away all together, but some day in future you might get that headache again...

If we had a CURE... it would mean that humanity would NEVER have a headache again - it would never appear to begin with. See where i am coming from? ; )

So there is a big different between what is cure and what actually just helps temporarily both physically and mentally.

Let me share with all you some disturbing (for me as an ilustrated person) things about Homeopathy.

Once we all agree the basis of Homeopathy are absurd (because they INDEED are), let me show you some points:

1- Homeopathic treatments are succesfull way over the pure statistical chance. This is something in that even well informed skeptics agree. The scientific explanation is, as this video states, the "Placebo Effect". But, as nobody knows in scientific terms how this Effect actually works, I feel myself very unsatisfied with this pseudo-explanation that "explains" an unknown through another unknown...

2- Homeopathy adherents say they can prove it works because it can be used with good results on children and animals, that can not "believe" in Homeopathy to activate the Placebo Effect on themselves. Skeptics (and this video) say the Placebo Effect can be "transfered" to others. Again, as the Placebo Effect is a scientific unknown, their explanation has to construct "properties" (as "capacity to be transfered") for that unknown can work. This bothers me, because it's a pseudo-scientific answer from the scientific field.

3- But let's imagine this "transfer" is possible. How it works? This video (and informated skeptics) suggests that fathers, caregivers and veterinarians that use Homeopathy treat children or animals in some way "better" than that who use scientific medicine, "inducing" in them some (unknown) variation of that infamous Placebo Effect. This is too much out of line. This is not a scientific critique. It's simply not true that the owners of animals (mostly farmers) treat in some way "better" their animals when use homeopathic treatments than when they not. And if you say that, you have to prove it. You (the skeptic) have put the burden of proof over your own shoulders, and you have been in some sense backfired. You have not proved anything.

And that bothers me, because the enigma remains unanswered. Does Homeopathy works? I some sense, yes it does. Are its fundaments absurd from a scientific point of view? Yes, they are. Result? We know nothing.

When I was 1 year old I suffered from asthma and my parents tried a few doctors before going to a homeopath; they gave them medicine that, according to my parents, "made you better for one or two days, then the recommendation was to stop administrating and you'd fall sick again in a day".

Their homeopath, who I still see to this day as a nutritionist (she had a degree in nutrition) finally changed this; their first visit there wasn't prescribing medicine, but a detailed questionnaire she made about their home, place they lived, habits and stuff like that.

She got my parents to move to my grandma's house which was in a much less humid place, got them to stop slacking about cleaning the house which lead to less dust in the air, got them to buy a big German Shepherd for me and my sister which was both amazing and slowly helped us work on our immune systems, got them to start having me and my sister go outside on open air more and more often, even signing me up to a baby swimming training, got them to be very strict about family members who smoked so they wouldn't smoke in the premises of their house and got them to give me a better diet than formula every meal.

And it was amazing, I got over my asthma symptoms in a few months and never felt them again if not for pollinating seasons and visits to horridly unclean and dusty places for a while.

Of course, she also gave them some sugar pills which did absolutely nothing, but her careful conversation with her patients got done something the real doctors didn't, she hunted the cause of the symptoms in their environment and got them to change it.

I wish more doctors would have the time for meetings like that, because sometimes knowing what your patient's life is like can be more or just as helpful as knowing the correct drug to treat their symptoms.

Mostly on the nose -- but you dropped the ball on placebos by suggesting that the placebo has "the desired effect" generally and that it works on animals and babies due to empathy with the caregiver. A better characterization is that placebos can have small positive effects on general symptoms like the perception of pain, but not on underlying causes like cancer -- which you note that placebos cannot cure. Further, the perceived effect on animals and babies is at least as much in the mind of the caregiver, being confirmation bias and regression to the mean, as it is in the lowered stress on the patient due to the caregiver being more calm.

To the person who said "Aren't vaccines another form of homeopathy?", I'm not gonna lie, I was a little angry at reading this at first, just due to the number of upvotes it had. But its no-one's fault, so I thought I'd settle this.

Vaccines are injections of a non-live virus . They are not active and cannot do harm to the body. They are specifically weakened, so that the immune system can produce the antibodies necessary to kill the virus in a safe manner. What's important about this is that the body does not know what antibodies to produce, so it produces a whole bunch and hopes to accidentally produce one which works (in a manner of speaking). Eventually, a correct antibody will be produced and it can fight off the virus. The cells that produced these antibodies remain in the blood, and this is important because if the virus were to reinfect in the future, the immune response is much faster because we already have the cells that can produce the antibodies necessary to kill the virus. This is factually and experimentally based.

Homeopathy does no such thing, after all, the substances which you place in your body are not things for the immune system to deal with. In the case of poisons like belladonna, for example, your body undergoes multiple procedures to flush out the poison, such as sweating, vomiting, diarrhoea, etc. None of these are systems which require the substance to be "killed". There is no reaction in the body which strengthens it against more of the same in the future.

I hope this clears it up slightly, for actual biologists, feel free to nitpick. Great new video @Kurzgesagt and anyone who made it this far should definitely read Bad Science, its a great book about debunking a lot of the "science" out there.

So, I've studied medicine for 7 semester and met a couple of people believing in homeopathy. Here's my point of view:
In my opinion homeopathy is OK as long as the illness you're treating with homeopathy is not going to seriously injure your body. As an example: If some1 caught a cold and says homeopathy helps him more than modern medicine: Go ahead and use it. A cold usually is cured in a couple of days anyways (regardless of you using medicine, homeopathy or nothing at all) and if you use less modern medicine you put your body under less stress (remember: medicine has to be processed by your organs and using too much damages them).
But what is NOT OK is when people with a serious disease, which could threaten your bodily functions or even your life, want to rely on homeopathy to treat it.
TL;DR: Small complaints (exp. Cold) can be treated with homeopathy. Anything major should be properly treated by a doctor with modern medicine.

You might not agree with my point of view but well, that's my opinion.

The way I figure the imbecile who invented homeopathy thought dosage worked, the "like cure like" thing, is a basic mathematical error. Take warfarin, for example, a commonly-used rat poison before it lost effectiveness due to evolution. It's still currently given to patients by doctors to help prevent blood clots, because that's what it does: it stops blood from clotting. A high dose (50mg or more) is lethal, but very small doses (less than 10mg) are safe, and even then they have to be carefully balanced with tests every week because it's still dangerous.
So knowing that very tiny doses of poison aren't automatically as lethal as high doses, all you need to do is mathematically represent "a thing causes a symptom" as X/1, and then perform a failure of basic math and think a smaller dose is the same thing as the opposite, 1/X, and suddenly you think "if X/1 causes symptom, 1/X cures it", and poof, you suddenly have an entirely wrong-headed and incorrect idea of how to cure disease.

Cue the dilution thing as a method of reducing doses, which is a further mistake in not understanding how chemistry works. Tylenol doesn't become more effective if you drink five gallons of water with your pill, because no matter how much water you end up drinking you're still only getting 325mg of Tylenol/paracetamol/acetaminophen from the pill. If you dissolve the pill, it doesn't matter; if you drink the entire thing, you're still only getting 325mg. If you only drink a single drop of five gallons of water with one pill dissolved in it, you're getting almost no medication whatsoever, which means there simply isn't any acetaminophen affecting your body chemistry to have an effect. The idea that water magically knows the medicinal properties of whatever medicinal (or in the case of homeopathy, non-medicinal but believed to be so by imbeciles) substance you're sticking in there is absurd. If it were true that water takes on the medicinal properties, then simply taking more medication would have the same effect; if a dilution of 500mg of Tylenol is twice as effective then taking two pills would match it perfectly, but in reality a dilution is less effective. If dilution truly increased the effectiveness, then you should regularly see overdoses from homeopathy patients who are taking an amount of medication greater than the spherical volume of an entire star system. It also begs the question of where water got its medical degree, to know that medicinal properties are good but things like taste and color and non-medicinal toxic properties shouldn't be "remembered". Water, it shouldn't need saying, does not have a medical degree.

The stupid doesn't stop there. If homeopathy had any merit, then taking extra-strength Tylenol should be less effective than regular strength, because 500mg is more medication than 325mg and according to homeopathy less is more effective. This should be true of all medication, in fact; merely scratching a single particle of dust off of a pill and breathing it in from across the room should be infinitely more effective a treatment than an IV drip. You should be able to perform surgery on someone merely by telling them "Hey, painkillers exist" instead of knocking them out through anesthesia.

The only effectiveness homeopathy can ever truly claim credit for belongs to the placebo effect, and as someone astutely pointed out, real medication has the placebo effect too. The difference of course is that real medication has an additional, real effect, whereas homeopathy does not.

Essentially, homeopathy is entirely based in a misunderstanding of pretty much everything to do with chemistry and medicine and even mathematics. It's a remarkable combination of utter failure.

I want to make a point that Nutrigenomics can be the root of what alternative medicine was based on. Homeopathy, which I've never studied does sound like hogwash. But alternative medicine is not. Nutrigenomics is a relatively new science that informs us that nutrition and our genes react to foods in a way that suggests natural healing through food is possible. It also suggests that many forms of alternative medicine, like the Dongui Bogam of Korea, understood this centuries before us. This is real science based on observation and tests. And although writings like Dongui Bogam are outdated and a result of their history does not mean they were stupid. They recognized diabetes, high blood pressure, and even dangerous pregnancies centuries before we could and handled their patients survival successfully. So, no, not all alternative medicine is hogwash but homeopathy isn't alternative medicine. It's literally a placebo. And when we stop calling all alternative medicine placebos, maybe in a 100 years we can actually build ourselves outside of synthetically and artificially "healing" our bodies with bandaids like medications with a hundred symptoms including death.

I really love your insight towards the ever-growing healthcare industry. There needs to be a mixture of empathy and efficiency in order to attain the maximum possible standard of care. Perhaps some people will say that thoughts like these are too idealistic, but within a world where we assign as much consultation time we have for additional empathy with the patients, we can get a step closer to genuine informed consent, as well as provide a system that is more compassionate and social-based than the usual service-compensation relationship. We can also nurture people's mentalities properly as to inform them about the proper clinical trials, in order to avoid misconceptions and curb the many immoral and unethical random clinical trials that have been done over the decades (Willowbrook Hepatitis Exp., Stanford Prison Exp., World War II Japanese and German Human Exp., etc.), as well as abolish the autonomy-paternalistic contract just because doctors are considered as high-class professionals. This could lead to less vaccine scares and more informed decisions on medicine and healthcare for each family.

And although there still exists the problem of a profit-based health sector, I still believe that healthcare is a global right, and that the compensation for it is still a big issue to be talked about otherwise. (Kudos to Canada for free healthcare.) Though, all in all, this is just my two cents.
